page.title: 16B.B.C. Transmitting Station
page.content: The Thrumster station was built by the B.B.C. in 1956 as a transmitting and receiving station for T.V.and radio. The base is rented from Brit. Telecom and is now used only for storage and maintenance.Initially the base was manned and operated for 405 blk/white T.V. but this finished in 1983/84 when 625 lines for colour were introduced so a new station was built at Rumster 15km.S.W. Thrumster cont.with V.H.F. radio producing a high quality signal for Hi-Fi. As most people had vertical not horizontal car ariels a new system became necessary.The site for this was also to be Rumster,which is fully automatic.Due to the advent of micro- electronics a roomful of radio equip- ment now fits in the space of a cup- board.Thrumster today is the base for five maintenance engineers who super- vise an area from Tongue to Orkney.
